Award.AwardTitle: Direct Democracy and the Significance of the Framing of Proposals

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
What attributes make a law more or less likely to inspire consent of the governed? Voters may weigh the costs and benefits of proposed legislation, but in order for voters to form a considered judgment of the costs, they must be able to correctly perceive them, attribute them to the responsible policy makers, and evaluate them in terms of their moral values. Many public opinion surveys and laboratory studies document the everyday cognitive biases that make these tasks difficult even in the area of tax law where costs are explicit. Recent theory in behavioral public finance tells us that law itself may be designed to make informed decision-making easier, for example, by adjusting the timing of implementation or explicitly stating burdens and benefits in such a way that voters can more clearly perceive, attribute, and evaluate those costs and benefits. Insights from behavioral finance have not yet been well integrated into analysis of democratic processes. The research tests whether policy design features may help voters evaluate proposed laws. By bringing insights from behavioral finance to the process of direct democracy, this project will extend our understanding of both. This study will contribute to our knowledge of the legal conditions that make possible a sustainable system of public finance.

As one part of testing this framework, the project will collect and digitize the universe of ballot measures relevant to public finance in the analytical site, preserving an important record of democracy that will be made available on-line to researchers and the public. Digitizing these records will also permit a statistical analysis of which policy features affect how voters perceive and respond to the costs of public policy. The project will also train new scholars in the analytics of democracy and public finance, contributing to deepening citizens' understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 1986, the state of California has required all of its local governments to submit almost every tax increase to the voters for approval. In the thirty years since then, California’s local governments have put taxes to their voters more than 3,000 times. These elections have been an unprecedented experiment in direct democracy. They can teach us something about how voters respond to the framing of policy proposals.

We studied this question by collecting as many of those proposals as we could. We obtained lists of measures, and election results, including the percentage of voters who favored the tax increase, from the California Elections Data Archive (CEDA) and the California Debt and Investment Advisory Commission (CDIAC). We collected the sample ballots and the full text of the underlying bills or resolutions from local government agencies and libraries. All of the documents that we collected were digitized and deposited at the library of the University of California – San Diego, where they will be available to the public and to interested researchers.

We then created a database describing which measures had which policy design features. This database allowed us to test statistically which of several policy design features were associated with voter approval in a subset of these cases. During the period of the grant we analyzed the data describing 929 municipal measures put before voters in the years 1996 to 2010. 

We found that three policy design features were especially important. First, voters appeared to strongly prefer some kinds of taxes to others. In particular, voters favored transient occupancy taxes (or “hotel taxes”) over other categories of taxation. Second, voters appeared to judge ballot measures in part based on the particular categories of public spending for which the taxes were intended. Tax measures earmarked for emergency services, a category that includes police, fire, and emergency medical services, had the most support. Third, voters evaluated tax measures differently depending on whether the proposed tax rates had been implemented previously, or not. A greater share of voters would approve a measure to extend an existing tax rate that was otherwise scheduled to expire, than would approve a measure to increase an existing tax rate.

In the long run the findings of this study may help us to understand how voters reason about the costs and benefits of government in a democracy. We hope that the archive of ballot measures will create a permanent record of a unique American democratic experiment that will be useful for researchers and the public.
